titleStmt.title: Flores aliquot sententiarum ex variis collecti scriptoribus. = The flovvers of sencies gathered out of sundry wryters by Erasmus in Latine, and Englished by Richard Tauerner. Huic libello non male co[n]nuenient mimi illi publiani nuper ab eodem Richardi uersi
Aliquot sententiae insignes. English. Selections
titleStmt.author: Erasmus, Desiderius, d. 1536.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 17 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 12 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Flores aliquot sententiarum ex variis collecti scriptoribus. = The flovvers of sencies gathered out of sundry wryters by Erasmus in Latine, and Englished by Richard Tauerner. Huic libello non male co[n]nuenient mimi illi publiani nuper ab eodem Richardi uersi
Aliquot sententiae insignes. English. Selections
titleStmt.author: Erasmus, Desiderius, d. 1536.
Taverner, Richard, 1505?-1575.

publicationStmt.publisher: Ex ædibus Richardi Tauerner [by Richard Bankes],

notesStmt.note: A selection from Erasmus's collection "Aliquot sententiae insignes" that traditionally has been listed as selections from the "Apophthegmata". See "The Library", XIX (1964)--STC.
Each aphorism in Latin is followed by the English translation.
Colophon reads: "Printed in Fletestrete very diligently under the correction of the selfe Richard Tauerner, by Richard Bankes. Cum priulegio ad imprimendu[m] solum.
Imperfect; leaf A3 torn, affecting text.
Reproduction of the original in the Cambridge University Library.
Appears at reel 39:12 and at reel 79:3 (same copy (Cambridge University. Library) filmed twice).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Aphorisms and apothegms -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2004-03 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2004-04 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: ❧FLORES ALIQVOT SENTENTIARVM EX VARIIS collecti scriptoribus.
THE FLOVVERS OF SEN cies gathered out of sundry wryters by Erasmus in Latine, and Englished by Richard Tauerner.
Huic libello non male cōnuenient Mimi illi publiani nuper ab eodem Richardo uersi.
LONDINI.
Ex aedibus Richardi Tauerner.
Anno. M. D. XL.

div.head: RICHARDVS TAVERNErus Britannicae pubi. S. D.
div.p:
EN edo hic vobis, florentissima pubes Britannica, flores sententiarū nonnullos (sic enim hūc libellū appellare libet) a flore sui seculi Desiderio Erasmo Roterodamo olim excerptos, & modo a nobis dilucide magis
quam accurate in Anglicum sermonem versos. Quod si has nostras lucubratiunculas grata manu accipere non grauabimini: erit qd quod uehementer gaudeam. Ne
que enim un
quam me pigebit, quātumuis obstrepant Zoili, in commodum uestrum subinde repuerascere. Sinautem hij flosculi uidebuntur paulo minutiores, aut forsitan etiam nugaciores
quam ut in uulgus edantur (
quam
quam hae nugae quā tūuis minutae seria ducūt) animum certmeū uestri studiosissimū unprobare haud sane poteritis.

closer.dateline: Ex aula regia idibus Septembribus. Anno. M. D. XL.

div.head: ALIQVOT SENTENTIARVM flores ex uarijs collecti scriptoribus per Desid. Erasmū Roterodamum una cum interpretatione Richardi Tauerneri Serenissimo regi Angliae ab annulo Signatorio.
THE SAYENGES OF PITTACVS.
div.p: DIfficilia, quae pulchra. Goodly thinges be hard Magistratus uirū arguit. Authoritie or office vttereth what the man is. Prudētis est prospicere ne quid eueniat mali, fortis tolerare, si quid forte obtigerit.
It is a wise mans parte to forse that no euyl do chaunce vnto him, and agayne it is an hardy mans parte to suffre if any euyl do chaunce hym.

p.hi: Ne cui calamitatem suam exprobra ris.

div.p: Upbrayd noman of his misfortune.

p.hi: Vxorem aequalem ducito.

div.p: Marry a wyfe of no hygher byrth or state then thou art thy selfe.

div.head: Bias.

p.hi: Valere corpore, naturae munus est, Diuitiae dantur a fortuna, Sapientia animi bonum est.

div.p: To be strong of body is the gyfte of nature, Riches is gyuen of fortune, and wysedome is the good thyng of the mynde.

p.hi: Ita dispēsa tempus, quasi & diu uicturus, & mox moriturus.

div.p: So dispose thy tym 〈…〉 dest both liue lōg, & a 〈…〉

p.hi:
Delibera lente, quod dec 〈…〉
•••• stanter urge.

div.p: Take long aduisemēt, but the that thou hast ones determined set vpon it constantly.

p.hi: Ne praeceps sis ad loquendum.

div.p: Be not heady or rashe to speake.

p.hi: Pessimi consultores sunt ira & praecipitantia.

div.p: Wrath & rashenes be two the worste counsaylers that can be.

p.hi: Sapiens oīa sua bona secum portat.

div.p: The wise man carieth al his goodes wyth hym.

div.head: Cleobulus.

p.hi: Amicos beneficijs foue, quo fiant amiciores, inimicis benefac, quo fiant amici.

div.p:
〈…〉 frendes wyth bene
〈…〉 hem more fredly, and 〈…〉 thyne enemyes, to make 〈…〉 rendes.

p.hi: 〈…〉 urus domo, tecum expendito 〈…〉 id foris agere uelis, domum ubi 〈…〉 edieris, quid egeris reputato.

div.p: Whē thou goest from home, pondre wyth thy selfe what thou wylt do abrode. And whē thou returnest home recorde with thy self what thou hast done.

p.hi:
Audiēdi
quam loquēdi studiosior esto.

div.p: Be more desyrouse to heare, then to speake.

p.hi: Voluptati frenos inijcito.

div.p: Brydle thy pleasoure.

p.hi: Vxori praesētibus alijs nec blandire nec iurgium facito.

div.p:
In presence of other, neyther flatter
thy wyfe nor chyde her.

p.hi: Rebus secūdis ne efferaris, aduersis ne deijciaris.

div.p: Wyth prosperetie be thou not lyfted vp, and wyth aduersitie be not caste downe.

div.head: Periander.

p.hi: Voluptas cito perit, honos immortalis est.

div.p: Pleasure sone perisheth, but honour neuer dyeth.

p.hi: Tuta res quies, periculosa temeritas

div.p: Quietnes is a sure thynge but rashnesse is daungerouse.

p.hi: In rebus prosperis esto moderatus, in aduersis prudens.

div.p: In prosperitie be sobre, in aduersitie wyse

p.hi: Cura potest omnia.

div.p: Diligēce and study can do al thingꝭ.

div.head: Anacharsis.

p.hi: De arte non iudicat nisi artifex.

div.p: Of a crafte can no man iuge but the craftes man.

p.hi:
Ex alienis uitiis disce
quam foeda sint tua.

div.p: By other mennes vices lerne howe fowle thyne owne be.

p.hi: Linguā, uentrem, & pudēda cohibe.

div.p: Charme the tong, bely and preuites.

div.head: Thales.

p.hi: Difficillimū est omnium nosce seipsum.

div.p: It is the hardest poynt of all, a man to knowe himselfe.

p.hi: Quae in alijs damnes, ipse ne feceris.

div.p: Suche thynges as thou doste condemne and blame in other, do them not thy selfe.

p.hi:
Amicorum non minus absentium
quam
praesentium memores esse oportet.

div.p: It hehoueth vs to remembre oure frendes aswel absent as present.

p.hi:
Animus honestis artibus excolēdus est, potius
quam forma corporis componenda.

div.p: A man ought rather to garnishe his mynde wyth honest artes, then to decke the forme of hys body.

p.hi: Ne quaeras fraude ditescere.

div.p: Seke not to grow rych by falshode.

p.hi: Qualem gratiam retuleris parentibus tuis, talem expecta & a liberis tuis

div.p: Such thanke as thou hast yelded to thy parentes, loke for the lyke of thy chyldren.

div.head: Solon.

p.hi: Virtus fidelior est iureiurando.

div.p:
There is more trust in honestie then
in an othe.

p.hi: Quod praeclarum est, accurate agē dum.

div.p: A thynge of excellencie ought to be fynely done.

p.hi: Amicum ne temere recipito, receptum ne reijcito.

div.p: Receyue no man rashly into thy frēd shyp and when thou hast receyued him cast him not of.

p.hi: Impera, sed prius edoctus imperio parere.

div.p: Desyre to beare some rule, but fyrst lerne to be obedient vnto rule thy selfe.

p.hi: Cum regibus (dixit Aesopus) aut omnino non loquendum, aut quae sunt iucundissima loqui oportet.

div.p:
Wyth kinges (sayde Esope) it were best eyther not to speake at all, or to
speake thinges most pleasaunt.

p.hi: Immo, inquit Solon. Cum regibus aut omnino non loquendū, aut quae sunt optima loqui oportet.

div.p: Nay sayth Solon. With kinges it were best either not to speake at all, or to speake the best thinges.

p.hi: Rationi pareto.

div.p: Obey reason.

p.hi: Malorum consuetudinem fugito.

div.p: Eschue the felowshyp of euyl disposed men.

p.hi: In defunctum maledicta ne congerito.

div.p: Rayle not vpon him that is deade.

p.hi: Filius ne parentem alere cogitor, a quo nullam artem edoctus est.

div.p:
Lette not the sonne be compelled to fynde his father in his extreme pouerte and nede, of whom he hath not
bene taughte or brought vp in anye science or occupation.

p.hi: Vitae finem spectato.

div.p: Praise no man for blessed and happy till thou se the ende of his life.

div.head: Chilo Lacedaemonius.

p.hi: Si dixeris quae uis, audies quae non uis.

div.p: If thou speake what thou wilt, thou shalt heare what thou wilt not.

p.hi: Damnum turpi lucro potius esto.

div.p: Preferre dāmage afore fowle lucre.

p.hi: Ne lingua praeuertitor animum.

div.p: Lette not the tonge runne before the wytte.

p.hi: Quae fieri non possunt ne tentes.

div.p: Assaye not the thinges that can not be brought about.

p.hi: Index aurum, aurum explorat hominem.

div.p: The touche stone tryeth golde, gold tryeth man.

p.hi:
Amato tan
quam osurus, oderis tan
quam amaturus.

div.p: Loue as thoughe thou shuldest in tyme commynge hate, and hate as though thou shuldest in tyme commynge loue.

div.head: Aristippus.

p.hi: Opes eiusmodi tibi para, quae naui fracta simul cum domino enatent.

div.p: Seke the suche ryches whyche if the ship breake may swimme forth togither wyth the owner.

p.hi: Fortunae bona uarij casus eripiunt: bona animi quae sola uere bona sūt, nec incendium nec naufragium potest eripere.

div.p:
The goodes of fortune be taken awaye by sundrye casualties, but the
goodes of the mynde whiche be only the true goodes can be taken awaye neither by fyer nor by shypwrake.

p.hi: Disce puer, quae uiro sunt usui futura.

div.p: Lerne when thou art a chylde suche thynges as shalbe profitable to the when thou art a man.

div.head: Theophrastus.

p.hi: Preciocissimus sūptus est tempus.

div.p: Tyme is the most preciouse cost that a man can bestowe.

div.head: Antisthenes

p.hi: Regium est audire male, quum feceris bene.

div.p: It is gyuen to a kyng, though he do neuer so wel yet to be euyl spoken of.

p.hi:
Satius est in coraces
quam in colaces .i. in coruos
quam in adulatores incidere, Illi mortuū exedunt, hi uiuū etiam.

div.p: It is better of the tweyne, to fall amōges a sort of rauens, then amōgꝭ flatterers. The rauens eate a man when he is deade, but the flatterers eate him quycke.

p.hi: Quod rubigo est ferro, hoc liuor est homini.

div.p: That rust doth to yron, that doth en uye to man.

p.hi: Fratrum concordia quouis muro tutior.

div.p: The concord of brethrē is surer then any stone wale.

p.hi: Praecipua disciplina est dediscere ma la.

div.p: The chiefest lernynge is to vnlerne vices.

div.head: Diogenes

p.hi: Vir bonus dei simulachrum est.

div.p: A good man is the ymage of god.

p.hi: Amor ociosorum est negotium.

div.p: Loue is the busynes of loyterers.

p.hi: Miserrima res est senex egens.

div.p: Nedy age is a thing most miserable.

p.hi: Perniciosissime mordent, ex feris bestijs obtrectator, ex cicuribus adulator.

div.p: There be two whiche byte most dead ly, of wylde beastes, the backbyter, & of tame the flatterer.

p.hi: Oratio blanda est mellitus laqueus.

div.p: A flatterynge speach is a hony swete snare.

p.hi: Qui praeclare loquuntur nec faciunt, citharae similes sunt quae sonat alijs, ipsa nec audiens, nec sentiens.

div.p:
They that speake gloriously but do nothing therafter themselfes, be like to a harpe whiche maketh a sounde to other, but it selfe neither heareth
perceiueth.

p.hi: Frustra uiuit, cui ut bene uiuat nulla cura est.

div.p: He liueth vaynly which hath no care to liue well.

p.hi: Qui forma decorus indecore loquitur, ex eburnea uagina plumbium educit gladium.

div.p: A goodlye person that speaketh vngoodly wordes, draweth forth a leaden swerd out of an Iuery skaberd. Serui heris, improbi seruiunt cupiditatibus.
Bonde men be thralle to their maisters, and wicked men to their lustes. Eruditio iuuenibus sobrietas est, senibus solatium, pauperibus diuitiae, diuitibus ornamentum.

Lernyng is to yong men a sobrenes, to olde men a solace, to pore men ryches,
to ryche men a garnishment. Nobilitas, gloria, diuitiae, malitiae sunt uelamenta.
Nobilitie, glorie, riches be the clokes of naughtynes.

div.head: Socrates.

p.hi: Quae supra nos, nihil ad nos.

div.p: The thinges that be aboue vs, perteine nought vnto vs.

p.hi: Hoc unum scio, me nihil scire.

div.p: Thys one thynge I knowe that I knowe nothinge.

div.head: Crates.

p.hi:
Vt in omni malo punico granū aliquod putre est, ita nemo reperitur undiqua
que purus a uitio.

div.p: Like as in euery pome granat there is some kernel rotten: so there is no man foūd throughly cleane frō vice.

div.head: Zeno citiensis.

p.hi: Non qui magnus, statim bonus est, sed quisquis bonus, idem & magnus est.

div.p:
It foloweth not, that whosoeuer is greate is forthwyth good, but who soeuer is good, ye same is also great. Ideo natura dedit homini aures duas, os unicum, ut plus audiamus
quam loquamur.
Nature hath giuen mā therfore two eares and but one mouth, that we shulde be readyer to heare then to speake.

p.hi:
Auribus attrahēdi sūt homines potius
quam pallio, id est, persuasione magis
quam uiolentia.

div.p: Men ought to be drawen rather by the eares then by the gowne, that is to say, rather by perswasion than by violence.

div.head: Themistocles.

p.hi:
Praestat habere uiros egentes pecunia,
quam pecuniam egentem uiris.

div.p: It is better to haue men wantynge monye, then monye wanting men.

div.head: Pericles.

p.hi:
Amicum esse licet sed us
que ad aras.

div.p: A man may be a frende, but he must go no further wyth his frende then till he come to the aultar, that is, he may offend god for his frēdes cause.

div.head: Lamachus.

p.hi: Non licet in bello bis peccare.

div.p: It is not lawfull in battell to make a fawlte twyse.

div.head: Iphicrates

p.hi: Indecora sapienti uox est, Non putaram, aut non expectaram.

div.p:
It is an vncombly sayeng for a wise mā to say, I wold not haue thought
it, or I wolde not haue loked that it shulde haue come so to passe.

div.head: M. Curius.

p.hi:
Praestantius est imperare aurum habentibus uiris,
quam habere aurum.

div.p: It is farre better for a man to beare a rule vpon men hauyng golde, then to haue golde himselfe.

div.head: Cato senior.

p.hi:
Mirum eam ciuitatem saluam esse posse, in qua minoris uen 〈…〉 os
quam piscis.

div.p: It is meruayle that that citie can be saufe, in which an oxe is sold for lesse price, then a fishe is solde for.

div.head: Musonius apud Gellium.

p.hi: Si per laborem honesti quippiam egeris, labor abit, honestum manet: si per uoluptatem turpe quippiam
feceris, uoluptas abit, turpitudo ma net.

div.p: If through labour thou shalt worke any worshyp: the laboure vanisheth, and the worship taryeth. But if thorough pleasure thou shalt work any shame, the pleasure vanisheth and the shame tarieth.
Printed in Fletestrete very diligently vnder the correction of the selfe Richard Tauerner, by Richard Bankes.

p.hi: CVM PRIVILEGIO ad imprimendū solum.
